#Text=DAVID LANGSTON , A Harvester of the Woods .
#Text=RUTH JAMESON , A Girl of the City .
#Text=GRANNY MORELAND , An Interested Neighbour . DR . CAREY , Chief Surgeon of the Onabasha Hospital . MRS . CAREY , Wife of the Doctor . DR .
#Text=HARMON , Who Concludes to Leave the City .
#Text=MOLLY BARNET , A Hospital Nurse with a Heart .
#Text=HENRY JAMESON , A Trader Without a Heart .

#Text=THE KENNEDYS , Philadelphia Lawyers .
#Text=THE HARVESTER
#Text=CHAPTER I. BELSHAZZAR'S DECISION
#Text=“ Bel , come here ! ”

#Text=The Harvester sat in the hollow worn in the hewed log stoop by the feet of his father and mother and his own sturdier tread , and rested his head against the casing of the cabin door when he gave the command .
#Text=The tip of the dog 's nose touched the gravel between his paws as he crouched flat on earth , with beautiful eyes steadily watching the master , but he did not move a muscle .
#Text=“ Bel , come here ! ”
#Text=Twinkles flashed in the eyes of the man when he repeated the order , while his voice grew more imperative as he stretched a lean , wiry hand toward the dog .
#Text=The animal 's eyes gleamed and his sensitive nose quivered , yet he lay quietly .
#Text=“ Belshazzar , kommen Sie hier ! ”
#Text=The body of the dog arose on straightened legs and his muzzle dropped in the outstretched palm .

#Text=A wind slightly perfumed with the odour of melting snow and unsheathing buds swept the lake beside them , and lifted a waving tangle of light hair on the brow of the man , while a level ray of the setting sun flashed across the water and illumined the graven , sensitive face , now alive with keen interest in the game being played .
#Text=“ Bel , dost remember the day ? ” inquired the Harvester .
#Text=The eager attitude and anxious eyes of the dog betrayed that he did not , but was waiting with every sense alert for a familiar word that would tell him what was expected .
#Text=“ Surely you heard the killdeers crying in the night , ” prompted the man .
#Text=“ I called your attention when the ecstasy of the first bluebird waked the dawn .
#Text=All day you have seen the gold-yellow and blood-red osiers , the sap-wet maples and spring tracing announcements of her arrival on the sunny side of the levee . ”
#Text=The dog found no clew , but he recognized tones he loved in the suave , easy voice , and his tail beat his sides in vigorous approval .
#Text=The man nodded gravely .
#Text=“ Ah , so !
#Text=Then you realize this day to be the most important of all the coming year to me ; this hour a solemn one that influences my whole after life .
#Text=It is time for your annual decision on my fate for a twelve-month .
#Text=Are you sure you are fully alive to the gravity of the situation , Bel ? ”
#Text=The dog felt himself safe in answering a rising inflection ending in his name uttered in that tone , and wagged eager assent .
#Text=“ Well then , ” said the man , “ which shall it be ?
#Text=Do I leave home for the noise and grime of the city , open an office and enter the money-making scramble ? ”
#Text=Every word was strange to the dog , almost breathlessly waiting for a familiar syllable .
#Text=The man gazed steadily into the animal 's eyes .
#Text=After a long pause he continued :
#Text=“ Or do I remain at home to harvest the golden seal , mullein , and ginseng , not to mention an occasional hour with the black bass or tramps for partridge and cotton-tails ? ”
#Text=The dog recognized each word of that .
#Text=Before the voice ceased , his sleek sides were quivering , his nostrils twitching , his tail lashing , and at the pause he leaped up and thrust his nose against the face of the man .
#Text=The Harvester leaned back laughing in deep , full-chested tones ; then he patted the dog 's head with one hand and renewed his grip with the other .
#Text=“ Good old Bel ! ” he cried exultantly .
#Text=“ Six years you have decided for me , and right -- --every time !
#Text=We are of the woods , Bel , born and reared here as our fathers before us .
#Text=What would we of the camp fire , the long trail , the earthy search , we harvesters of herbs the famous chemists require , what would we do in a city ?
#Text=And when the sap is rising , the bass splashing , and the wild geese honking in the night ! We never could endure it , Bel .
#Text=“ When we delivered that hemlock at the hospital to-day , did you hear that young doctor talking about his ' lid ' ?
#Text=Well up there is ours , old fellow ! Just sky and clouds overhead for us , forest wind in our faces , wild perfume in our nostrils , muck on our feet , that 's the life for us .
#Text=Our blood was tainted to begin with , and we 've lived here so long it is now a passion in our hearts .
#Text=If ever you sentence us to life in the city , you 'll finish both of us , that 's what you 'll do !
#Text=But you wo n't , will you ?
#Text=You realize what God made us for and what He made for us , do n't you , Bel ? ”
